title: spack view needs to install sitecustomize.py for easy_install.pth to be found
body:
(I just wanted to open an issue since this was not obvious to me and should perhaps be fixed in the spack view code.)

When using #3227 to create a spack view that both contains python and a python package installed as a `.egg` file (i.e. present in `easy_install.pth`), a python process started via the spack view path fails to import that package.
As explained in e.g. https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/site.html, python will look inside the `site-packages` directory relative to `sys.exec_prefix` and `sys.prefix` for `.pth` files:
> Importing this module will append site-specific paths to the module search path and add a few builtins.
> It starts by constructing up to four directories from a head and a tail part. For the head part, it uses sys.prefix and sys.exec_prefix; empty heads are skipped. 

But those do not point into the filesystem view but to the install directory of the package:

```
In [3]: sys.exec_prefix
Out[3]: '/path/to/spack/opt/spack/linux-debian8-x86_64/gcc-4.9.2/python-2.7.13-jtpih7wfgjrzzk4reevynswu54pmif5m'

In [4]: sys.prefix
Out[4]: '/path/to/spack/opt/spack/linux-debian8-x86_64/gcc-4.9.2/python-2.7.13-jtpih7wfgjrzzk4reevynswu54pmif5m'
```
Consequently python will not see the `easy_install.pth` created by `spack view`. I was able to work around this by using `export PYTHONUSERBASE=/path/to/spack/spackview/`.

But perhaps `spack view` should create a `sitecustomize.py` inside the `site-packages` of the view directory to adjust the site prefix path such that `sys.prefix` points to the filesystem view:
> After these path manipulations, an attempt is made to import a module named `sitecustomize`, which can perform arbitrary site-specific customizations.
> `site.addsitedir(sitedir, known_paths=None)`
>    Add a directory to sys.path and process its .pth files. Typically used in sitecustomize or usercustomize (see above).

From looking at #5415 this issue still is present in the merged version. Maybe @mathstuf or @obreitwi can share their thoughts.
